# Tyson Foods (TSN) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

Tyson Foods, Inc. (NYSE: TSN) is a world-class food company and recognized leader in protein. The Company is unified by this purpose: Tyson Foods. We Feed the World Like Family™ and has a broad portfolio of iconic products and brands including Tyson®, Jimmy Dean®, Hillshire Farm®, Ball Park®, Wright®, State Fair®, Aidells® and ibp®. Tyson Foods is dedicated to bringing high-quality food to every table in the world, safely, sustainably, and affordably, now and for future generations. Headquartered in Springdale, Arkansas, the company had approximately 138,000 team members as of September 2024. Founded in 1935 by John W. Tyson, it has grown under four generations of family leadership.

The company operates through four segments: Beef, Pork, Chicken, and Prepared Foods. The company processes live fed cattle and hogs; fabricates dressed beef and pork carcasses into primal and sub-primal meat cuts, as well as case ready beef and pork, and fully cooked meats; raises and processes chickens into fresh, frozen, and value-added chicken products, including breaded chicken strips, nuggets, patties, and other ready-to-fix or fully cooked chicken parts; and supplies poultry breeding stock. The company is the world's second-largest processor and marketer of chicken, beef, and pork after JBS S.A. It is the largest meat company in America.

## 2. Current Market Data

The Tyson Foods Inc stock price today is 59.00. Tyson Foods market cap as of January 09, 2026 is $20.49B. Current market data shows Market Cap at 20.49B, Enterprise Value at 28.09B, Trailing P/E at 43.64, Forward P/E at 15.11, PEG Ratio (5yr expected) at 0.33, and Price/Sales (ttm) at 0.38.

The stock has fluctuated within a day range of 57.82 to 59.02, while its 52-week range spans from 50.56 to 64.36. The average 12-month price target for Tyson Foods is USD64.41667, with a high estimate of USD80 and a low estimate of USD55.

## 3. Existing Products/Services

Chicken and beef are its two largest segments, composing about 40% and 30% of sales, respectively. Prepared foods constituted 18% of fiscal 2025 sales and include brands like Tyson, Jimmy Dean, Hillshire Farm, Ball Park, and Sara Lee.

It also manufactures and markets frozen and refrigerated food products, including ready-to-eat sandwiches, flame-grilled hamburgers, Philly steaks, pepperoni, bacon, breakfast sausage, turkey, lunchmeat, hot dogs, flour and corn tortilla products, appetizers, snacks, prepared meals, ethnic foods, side dishes, meat dishes, breadsticks, and processed meats under the Tyson, Jimmy Dean, Hillshire Farm, Ball Park, Wright, Aidells, Gallo Salame, ibp, and State Fair brands.

Tyson Foods is also the leading protein provider to many national restaurant chains, including quick service, casual, mid-scale and fine-dining restaurants. We make great food for a variety of foodservice customers, including schools, military bases, hospitals, nursing homes and international customers, as well. We are also the only company that sells chicken, beef, pork, and prepared foods products through all major retail distribution channels, including club stores, grocery stores, and discount stores.

## 4. Planned Products/Services/Projects

New product innovations include Tyson® brand inspiring fans with new culinary innovations that celebrate fandom and inspire a protein-packed tailgate this football season. Tyson Foods is turning up the flavor and bringing new energy to the lunch meat category with the launch of Hillshire Farm® Sandwich Style Lunch Meats in three bold new flavors. Discover Hillshire Snacking Dips & Spreads from Tyson Foods—chef-inspired, single-serve premium protein snacks, perfect for busy, on-the-go lifestyles.

Embark on a colossal, fun-filled adventure with Tyson Foods' latest creation – Tyson Mega Dino Nuggets! These playful, protein-packed nuggets are your passport to a prehistoric party, perfect for both kids and anyone...

The new facility represent an opportunity for Tyson Foods to innovate with new bacon flavors, cuts and products such as fully cooked bacon. "Bacon is a growing category based on consumer demand, both at home and at restaurants, and our expanded production will enable us to lead this growth and drive innovation," says Melanie Boulden, group president of prepared foods and chief growth officer.

Tyson Demo Day 2025 will focus on advancing artificial intelligence in food technology, emphasizing consumer and customer brand engagement, innovation in research and development, and reimagining product development processes.

## 5. Growth Strategy

Tyson Foods is heavily investing in value-added product lines, including prepared foods and snacks. This strategy aims to capitalize on consumer demand for convenience and higher-margin products.

Our multi-protein, multi-channel portfolio, combined with our best-in-class team, iconic brands and focus on operational excellence positions us well for Fiscal 2025 and beyond.

Specifically, the company is targeting having 50% of its volume be value added by the end of fiscal year 2024. "Using 2021 as a base, we have set volume targets across our company, which... Overall, we expect to grow our total company volume at 2% compound annual growth rate over the next three years, which will be roughly two-times the rate of expected protein consumption growth."

For example, in 2024, Tyson Foods continued to invest in advanced robotics and AI-driven systems to streamline its operations. In 2024, Tyson Foods continued to implement advanced automation in its processing plants.

## 6. Current and Potential Major Clients

More than 40% of Tyson Foods business is made up of consumer products sold through grocery stores. We collaborate with many of the nation's major grocery chains and other food retailers to develop choices and meal solutions today's consumers want, and the highest quality fresh and frozen products they expect.

These include major retail grocery chains, club stores, foodservice distributors, and national fast-food chains. It caters to restaurant chains, casual, mid-scale, and fine dining restaurants.

We sold products in approximately 140 countries and regions in fiscal 2024. Major sales markets include Australia, Canada, Central America, Chile, China, the European Union, the United Kingdom, Japan, Mexico, Malaysia, the Middle East, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan and Thailand.

## 7. Financial Data & Performance

In 2024 the company made a revenue of $53.61 Billion USD an increase over the revenue in the year 2023 that were of $52.94 Billion USD.

Net Sales: Up 1.6% year-over-year in Q4 and 0.8% for fiscal 2024. Cash Flow from Operations: Increased nearly $840 million for the year. CapEx: Just over $1.1 billion for the year. Net Leverage: Declined to 2.6 times, a 1.5 turns improvement versus fiscal 2023.

The Board also declared on November 8, 2024 a quarterly dividend of $0.50 per share on our Class A common stock and $0.45 per share on our Class B common stock, payable on March 14, 2025. We anticipate the remaining quarterly dividends in fiscal 2025 will be $0.50 and $0.45 per share of our Class A and Class B common stock, respectively. This results in an annual dividend rate in fiscal 2025 of $2.00 for Class A shares and $1.80 for Class B shares, or a 2% increase compared to the fiscal 2024 annual dividend rate.

## 8. Headwinds & Tailwinds

### Headwinds:
Tyson's beef business segment, which reflects the headwinds of limited cattle supply and spread compression during the first half of the year... In the beef segment, the quarterly volatility resulted in lackluster first half results that King said were expected, as the entire beef industry copes with fewer animals.

The company projects an adjusted operating loss of $375 million to $475 million for its beef segment in fiscal year 2025 due to historically low cattle availability and high prices.

Cattle inventories have declined to the lowest level in 70 years as drought affects key ranching regions.

The consumer is under pressure, especially the lower income households. "In retail, we're seeing roughly 20% cumulative inflation over the last three years. Now, the inflation impact, coupled with historically low savings rates, has created a more cautious, price-sensitive consumer."

### Tailwinds:
While we are benefiting from better market conditions, including lower grain costs, our bold actions and focus on the fundamentals are also evident in our results.

For 2025, we expect Prepared Foods and Chicken to deliver approximately 50% of our AOI, with a 10% growth at midpoint. We anticipate growth in Prepared Foods and Chicken, with stable performance in Pork and Beef. Prepared Foods is expected to see double-digit AOI growth in 2025, driven by operational improvements, core distribution growth, and innovation.

## 9. Market Shares

In the United States, it stands as an undisputed leader across several key segments. For fiscal year 2024, the company reported total sales of approximately $53.31 billion, marking a modest increase of 0.8% from the previous year. Notably, chicken and beef each contribute roughly one-third to its U.S. sales, while prepared foods accounted for 18% of fiscal 2024 sales, indicating a strategic emphasis on value-added products.

The company's ability to maintain a significant market share in its Beef and Pork segments, which each comprise about one-third of US sales, is a testament to its robust supply chain and operational efficiency. The Prepared Foods segment, accounting for roughly 20% of sales, benefits from well-established brands that resonate with consumers, driving loyalty and repeat purchases.

## 10. Comparison to Competitors

JBS S.A. is a global leader in the meat processing industry and Tyson Foods' most significant competitor. Headquartered in Brazil, JBS operates in over 150 countries and has a diversified product portfolio that includes beef, chicken, and pork. Cargill is a major player in the global food industry, offering a wide range of products and services. While not exclusively focused on meat, Cargill's protein segment is a formidable competitor to Tyson Foods.

Pilgrim's Pride, Hormel Foods, Conagra Brands, The J.M. Smucker Company, and Campbell's are some of the 48 competitors of Tyson Foods (Food Products).

Tyson Foods occupies a commanding position within the global protein sector, consistently ranking among the top three largest meat processors worldwide. In the United States, it stands as an undisputed leader across several key segments.

## 11. Partnerships, Mergers and Acquisitions

In March 2024, it was announced Tyson Foods had sold its broiler processing plant, hatchery and feed mill in Dexter, Missouri to the American fresh egg producer, Cal-Maine Foods for an undisclosed amount.

Cargill announced in early 2025 that it would close the Springdale plant, which employed about 1,000 people and had a network of approximately 100 growers. Tyson Poultry President Nathan McKay appeared before the Springdale City Council in November, informing the council of its intent to purchase the plant.

Lineage Inc. announced the acquisition of four existing cold storage warehouses and other related assets from Tyson Foods Inc. for $247 million. Following the transaction, Lineage will onboard over 1,000 Tyson Foods employees.

To meet increased market demand for protein, Tyson Foods will expand and modernize its facility in Robards. Today, Gov. Andy Beshear highlighted further food and beverage manufacturing growth in Kentucky as Tyson Foods announced a nearly $23.5 million investment in an expansion and modernization of its Henderson County facility that will support retention of over 1,100 jobs.

## 12. Recent Developments

Tyson Foods, Inc. announced the appointment of Devin Cole as Chief Operating Officer (COO).

Tyson Foods announced the appointment of Sarah Bond as a new independent director on its board, effective immediately.

Tyson Foods, Inc. announced the appointment of Olivia Tyson and John Randal Tyson as new directors, effective May 8, 2025.

In October 2025, Tyson agreed to pay $85 million to settle the lawsuit.

Tyson Foods announced on Friday that it will close a major beef plant in Nebraska in January amid a decline in U.S. cattle supplies. The meatpacking giant is set to close a plant in Lexington, Nebraska, with about 3,200 employees. The company also said it will scale back its operations at a beef plant in Amarillo, Texas, moving to a single, full-capacity shift in a move that will affect about 1,700 workers.

## 13. AI Investment Rating & Fair Value Assessment

Based on the comprehensive analysis of Tyson Foods (TSN), considering both the challenges and opportunities:

**Buy Rating: 6.8/10**

**Fair Value Estimate: $68**

### Investment Rationale:

**Strengths:**
- Diversified multi-protein portfolio providing stability
- Strong operational improvements in chicken and prepared foods segments
- Successful cost reduction and efficiency initiatives  
- Strong cash flow generation and debt reduction efforts
- Market-leading positions across multiple protein categories
- Established brand portfolio with consumer loyalty

**Concerns:**
- Significant headwinds in beef segment due to cattle supply shortages
- Consumer pressure from inflation impacting demand
- Commodity price volatility affecting margins
- Plant closures indicating operational challenges

**Growth Catalysts:**
- For 2025, we expect Prepared Foods and Chicken to deliver approximately 50% of our AOI, with a 10% growth at midpoint. Prepared Foods is expected to see double-digit AOI growth in 2025, driven by operational improvements, core distribution growth, and innovation.
- Strong performance in higher-margin value-added products
- Automation and AI investments improving operational efficiency
- International expansion opportunities in growing protein markets

The stock appears undervalued at current levels given the company's operational turnaround efforts, strong chicken performance, and diversified revenue streams that partially offset beef segment challenges. While near-term headwinds persist, the long-term outlook for protein demand and Tyson's market-leading position support a moderate buy recommendation for growth-oriented investors with moderate risk tolerance.
tldr_summary:
Tyson Foods is a global protein leader processing and marketing chicken, beef, pork, and prepared food products across retail, foodservice, and international markets. With a $20.49B market cap, the company operates through four segments: Beef, Pork, Chicken, and Prepared Foods, maintaining market leadership in protein processing.

Key investment considerations include strategic focus on high-margin value-added products, targeting 50% value-added volume by 2024, and robust brand portfolio including Tyson, Jimmy Dean, and Hillshire Farm. Despite beef segment challenges from cattle supply shortages, the company demonstrates resilience through operational improvements in chicken and prepared foods, with anticipated 10% segment growth in 2025. International presence spans 140 countries, and ongoing investments in automation and AI promise operational efficiency.

The AI analysis provides a moderate "Buy" rating of 6.8/10 with a $68 fair value, reflecting potential for growth balanced against near-term market volatility.
